message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest tetanus, and the toxin responsible for this blocks the release of GABA from inhibitory interneurons, leading to increased motor neuron activity and muscle spasms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are indicative of tetanus, which is caused by the release of tetanus toxin in peripheral motor neurons. The toxin blocks the release of GABA, causing muscle spasms and rigidity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest tetanus, and the toxin responsible for these manifestations in tetanus blocks the release of GABA, leading to increased muscle activity and spasms. None of the other options are associated with tetanus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question suggest tetanus infection, and the toxin responsible for these manifestations blocks the release of GABA in motor neurons causing muscle rigidity and spasms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the boy has tetanus, and the toxin responsible for this blocks the release of GABA. This results in an over-activation of the muscles, leading to stiffness and spasms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest that the boy is suffering from tetanus, which is caused by the toxin produced by the bacteria Clostridium tetani. The toxin blocks the release of GABA in the spinal cord, leading to sustained muscle contractions and spasms.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest tetanus, and the toxin responsible blocks the release of GABA, leading to muscle rigidity and spasms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are consistent with tetanus infection. The toxin responsible for these symptoms is tetanospasmin, which blocks the release of GABA in the spinal cord, leading to uncontrolled motor activity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and clinical manifestations suggest the patient has tetanus. The toxin responsible for these manifestations blocks the release of GABA, leading to muscle spasms and stiffness. None of the other options are related to this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest tetanus infection, which is caused by a toxin produced by the bacteria Clostridium tetani. This toxin blocks the release of the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid), leading to muscle spasms and rigidity.
